div.head: Experiment title:
div.p: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies of Fe-C-N system at deep Earth's interior conditions *Elena Bykova (Bayerisches Geoinstitut, University of Bayreuth, Bayreuth, Germany)

div.head: Report:
div.p: A piece of 57 Fe was placed inside a 60 µm hole in a Re gasket, preindented to the thickness of 22 µm. The sample chamber was loaded with nitrogen, which served as a pressure-transmitting medium. We used BX90 diamond anvil cells equipped with Boehler-Almax type diamonds (culet diameter of 120 µm). The double-sided laser-heating systems of the beamlines ID18 and ID27 of ESRF were used to heat the sample at the three pressure points: 60, 106 and 130 GPa.

Whereas the starting material, a polycrystalline iron foil, gives characteristic Debye-Scherer rings in the diffraction pattern, after the laser-heating in solidified nitrogen, we clearly observed well defined, sharp diffraction spots from multiple grains of new high-pressure high-temperature phases (Figure 1). We were able to identify the diffraction spots belonging to certain domains, find their orientation matrices, refine the unit cell parameters, and solve structures of the new phases against single-crystal diffraction data.
Heating at 60 GPa resulted in the formation of novel iron nitrides FeN and FeN2 (Figure 2 a,b). FeN has B8-structure type, while FeN2 has the marcasite structure type (space group Pnnm).

Heating at higher pressures (106 and 130 GPa) resulted in the appearance of nitrogen-rich nitride FeN4. Accurately determined atomic coordinates and interatomic distances allowed us to unambiguously identify the bonding type within the nitrogen chains and show that FeN4 contains poly-[tetraz-1-ene-1,4-diyl] anions in its structure (Figure 2c). FeN4 is the first experimentally obtained and unambigously characterized nitride containing such polymeric nitrogen chains. (a) (b) (c) Figure 2. Crystal structures of FeN (a), FeN2 (b) and FeN4 (c). Blue balls show the position of nitrogen atoms, orange ballsiron atoms.
